info.headline: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued January 09 at 1:08PM EST until January 09 at 2:00PM EST by NWS Columbia
info.description: The National Weather Service in Columbia has issued a * Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Fairfield County in central South Carolina... Newberry County in central South Carolina... Eastern Edgefield County in central South Carolina... Western Lexington County in central South Carolina... Saluda County in central South Carolina... Northwestern Aiken County in central South Carolina... Northwestern Richland County in central South Carolina... * Until 200 PM EST. * At 107 PM EST, severe thunderstorms were located along a line extending from near Chester State Park to Johnston, moving northeast at 50 mph. HAZARD...70 mph wind gusts. SOURCE...Emergency management. IMPACT...Expect considerable tree damage. Damage is likely to mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings. * Locations impacted include... North Augusta, Lexington, Irmo, Newberry, Batesburg-Leesville, Winnsboro, Clearwater, VC Summer Nuclear Station, Highway 6 at Lake Murray Dam, Red Bank, Belvedere, Oak Grove, St. Andrews, Edgefield, Saluda, Johnston, Prosperity, Ridge Spring, Edgefield County Airport, and Monticello. This includes the following highways... Interstate 20 in South Carolina between mile markers 5 and 62. Interstate 26 between mile markers 64 and 106. Interstate 520 in South Carolina between mile markers 17 and 23. Interstate 77 between mile markers 33 and 50. TORNADO...POSSIBLE THUNDERSTORM DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE HAIL THREAT...RADAR INDICATED MAX HAIL SIZE...<.75 IN WIND THREAT...RADAR INDICATED MAX WIND GUST...70 MPH
info.instruction: Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly from severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the basement or small central room in a sturdy structure. For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a building. Severe thunderstorms can produce large capsizing waves and frequent lightning. If on or near Lake Murray move away from the water and take shelter! A Tornado Watch remains in effect until 600 PM EST for east central Georgia...and central South Carolina.
